ygData.subject: Re: [neat] IEX Update
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi, A few thoughts... Are you varying the input data in every generation? How good is the current champion, how many neurones in the current champion and what

Hi,
A few thoughts...

Are you varying the input data in every generation?
How good is the current champion, how many neurones in the current champion 
and what does the topology look like?
How about stepping down to a 1D one?

Maybe the problem is not so well stated as we throught.  E.g. the net is 
inherently able to average between input values, which is not part of the 
problem domain (in this exact case, I know you want it elsewhere).  This 
may mean that in each generation, there are quite a lot of coincidentally 
good values (e.g. where an average drawn from irrelevant input cells 
happens to match a desired result).  How about testing in this way:

For each coordinate:
         Set that input to Rand1
         Set all other inputs to Rand2

         Test...

         Set that input to Rand3
         Set all other inputs to Rand4

         Test...
Next

That way it's _only_ way to get the correct answer is to go looking in the 
correct cell...

Just a thought.

OTOH, maybe you have a subtle bug, or may you just need to wait longer (and 
longer, and longer...).

Don't get disheartened, you'll get there eventually!

         Ian Badcoe

At 16:05 09/09/2004, you wrote:
>Well, I'm still trying to evolve a solution to that 3x3 multiplexer.
>Almost 236,000 generations, but only 1735 distinct topological
>variations tried and optimized so far.  I don't think it's managed to
>make a serious improvement in over 1000 topologies.
>
>*sigh*
>
>This is what I get for making the search *more* thorough, and then
>throwing it at a large problem domain that requires complex
>topologies.  Well, hopefully in the near future I'll have some time to
>do something about it.
>
>
